channel.title: Need help with PHP
channel.description:
Ok, PHP is my worst web design subject :P
So, anyways I was wondering how I could do
/index.php?action=blahblahblah
Anyone know how?

item.title: Need help with PHP
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Clear, post:5, topic:159173”][quote author=S!ms link=topic=216792.msg1888232#msg1888232 date=1195604038]
To be clear: ?name=value, will be used as $_GET[‘name’] = value
[/quote]

OK, but how would you make it call from “blah.php” then?[/quote]blah.php?name=value

blah.php would have all the stuff you’d need to handle the GET variable stuff 'n such.

blah.php:

[code]

<?php echo $_GET['name'] . ' ORLYTLROLYOLROLYG'; ?>[/code]

Read full topic

item.description:
@Clear wrote:

Lol, OK Thanks

I’ll see if I can get it to work for me, seeing as I suck at php

Thanks It worked,

http://www.runeore.org/chat/index.php?id=Home

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with PHP
item.dc:creator: @S_ms S!ms
item.description:
@S_ms wrote:

yeh, then use a script i wrote a while ago.

<?php # Toegestaande pagina's $allowed_pages = array( 'Home', 'Hoe het begon', 'Errors enzo', 'Gastenboek', 'Contact' ); # Is id gedeclareerd? if (! isset($_GET['id']) ) { $page = 'Home'; } else { $page = $_GET['id']; } # Even wat variabelen declareren. $sitenaam = 'Windows sucks'; $uppercase = ucfirst($page); if (in_array($uppercase, $allowed_pages)) # Zit de pagina in de toegestaande pagina's? { $titel = $uppercase; # Zoja, declareer de titel. $include = $page.'.php'; } else { $page = '404'; # Zo nee, maak een 404 pagina. $titel = 'Error 404'; $include = '404.php'; } ?>

Comments are in dutch, put them into a translate machine.

Little explanation:
If id (?index.php?id=Gastenboek) is defined, the page will be included, otherwise home will. However, if it is defined but doesnt excist and isnt allowed, a 404 will be included.

This does also generate a title, might be useful.

You should use in your body:

<?php require($include); ?>

to include the page itself and

<?php echo $titel ?>

to display the title

hope it helps.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with PHP
item.dc:creator: @OnlyOneRule OnlyOneRule
item.description:
@OnlyOneRule wrote:

[quote=“TestDummy, post:2, topic:159173”]That involves GET.

For starters, your form has to start something like

And then, assuming you already know some HTML and PHP, you’d utilize the name in a HTML form element, like this.

Which would be a text input box, which we called ‘foo’.

In PHP, you’d refer to this as $_GET[‘foo’]

In your case, it could go like

The corresponding GET would be $_GET[‘action’]

You’d substitute the appropriate form input for the job, just remember stuff like dropdowns need the name in the tag, not the tags.

GET stuff appears in the address bar when you submit the data.

I know it isn’t a perfect explanation, but hopefully it made some sense.[/quote]
It doesn’t nessaceraly need to be a forum.

Al you need to know is how to use the get array:

[php]

<?php echo "the value of action is {$_GET['action']}"; ?>[/php]

Read full topic

item.title: Need help with PHP
item.dc:creator: @TestDummy TestDummy
item.description:
@TestDummy wrote:

That involves GET.

For starters, your form has to start something like

And then, assuming you already know some HTML and PHP, you’d utilize the name in a HTML form element, like this.

Which would be a text input box, which we called ‘foo’.

In PHP, you’d refer to this as $_GET[‘foo’]

In your case, it could go like

The corresponding GET would be $_GET[‘action’]

You’d substitute the appropriate form input for the job, just remember stuff like dropdowns need the name in the tag, not the tags.

GET stuff appears in the address bar when you submit the data.

I know it isn’t a perfect explanation, but hopefully it made some sense.
